frontmatter.title: Google Cloud CMIP6 Public Data: Basic Python Example

children.value: This notebooks shows how to query the Google Cloud CMIP6 catalog and load the data using Python.

from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import xarray as xr
import zarr
import fsspec
import nc_time_axis

%matplotlib inline
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = 12, 6
The data catatalog is stored as a CSV file. Here we read it with Pandas.

text/plain.content:

children.value: The columns of the dataframe correspond to the
Here we filter the data to find monthly surface air temperature for historical experiments.

df_ta = df.query("activity_id=='CMIP' & table_id == 'Amon' & variable_id == 'tas' & experiment_id == 'historical'")
df_ta

children.value: Now we will load a single store using

# get the path to a specific zarr store (the first one from the dataframe above)
zstore = df_ta_ncar.zstore.values[-1]
print(zstore)

# create a mutable-mapping-style interface to the store
mapper = fsspec.get_mapper(zstore)

# open it using xarray and zarr
ds = xr.open_zarr(mapper, consolidated=True)
ds

children.value: Plot a map from a specific date:
The global mean of a lat-lon field needs to be weighted by the area of each grid cell, which is proportional to the cosine of its latitude.
We can pass all of the temperature data through this function:
